natural problem: On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots?
natural solution: The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.

Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.

Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes odd_probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "odd_probability = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1, 3, 5}. (n * (6 - n)) / 21)"
shows  "odd_probability = 11 / 21"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes odd_probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "odd_probability = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1, 3, 5}. (n * (6 - n)) / 21)"
shows  "odd_probability = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled. Find the probability of rolling an odd number. The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. 0 \<le> p \<and> p \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability 1 = 1 / 6"
and h2 : "probability 3 = 3 / 6"
and h3 : "probability 5 = 5 / 6"
and h4 : "probability 2 = 2 / 6"
and h5 : "probability 4 = 4 / 6"
and h6 : "probability 6 = 6 / 6"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>p. odd p) = 11 / 21"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. 0 \<le> p \<and> p \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability 1 = 1 / 6"
and h2 : "probability 3 = 3 / 6"
and h3 : "probability 5 = 5 / 6"
and h4 : "probability 2 = 2 / 6"
and h5 : "probability 4 = 4 / 6"
and h6 : "probability 6 = 6 / 6"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>p. odd p) = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A six-sided die has probabilities for each of its faces. The probability of rolling a 1 is $\frac{1}{6}$, a 2 is $\frac{2}{6}$, a 3 is $\frac{3}{6}$, a 4 is $\frac{4}{6}$, a 5 is $\frac{5}{6}$, and a 6 is $\frac{6}{6}$. What is the probability of rolling an odd number? The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
shows  "P = 11 / 21"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
shows  "P = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find a value of $P$ between 0 and 1 (inclusive) such that $P = \frac{11}{21}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die :: "nat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die n \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die n \<le> 1"
and h2 : "sum die {1..6} = 1"
shows  "die 1 + die 3 + die 5 = 11 / 21"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes die :: "nat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die n \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die n \<le> 1"
and h2 : "sum die {1..6} = 1"
shows  "die 1 + die 3 + die 5 = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A fair die has probabilities assigned to each face such that the sum of the probabilities of all faces is 1. If the probabilities for faces 1, 3, and 5 are non-negative and at most 1, what is the sum of these probabilities? The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die_faces :: "nat set"
and odd_faces :: "nat set"
and removed_dot_possibilities :: nat
assumes h0 : "die_faces = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "odd_faces = {x \<in> die_faces. odd x}"
and h2 : "removed_dot_possibilities = (\<Sum>x\<in>die_faces. x)"
and h3 : "card odd_faces = card {x \<in> die_faces. odd (x - 1)}"
shows  "real (card odd_faces) / real removed_dot_possibilities = 11 / 21"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes die_faces :: "nat set"
and odd_faces :: "nat set"
and removed_dot_possibilities :: nat
assumes h0 : "die_faces = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "odd_faces = {x \<in> die_faces. odd x}"
and h2 : "removed_dot_possibilities = (\<Sum>x\<in>die_faces. x)"
and h3 : "card odd_faces = card {x \<in> die_faces. odd (x - 1)}"
shows  "real (card odd_faces) / real removed_dot_possibilities = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a six-sided die with faces numbered from 1 to 6. Let "die_faces" represent the set of all possible face values, and "odd_faces" represent the set of odd face values. Calculate the ratio of the number of odd face values to the sum of all possible face values, assuming that the number of odd face values remains the same after subtracting one dot from each face. The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes standard_die_probability :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> standard_die_probability n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "standard_die_probability n = 0"
shows  "((standard_die_probability 1 + standard_die_probability 3 + standard_die_probability 5) - (standard_die_probability 2 + standard_die_probability 4 + standard_die_probability 6)) / 6 = 11 / 21"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes standard_die_probability :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> standard_die_probability n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "standard_die_probability n = 0"
shows  "((standard_die_probability 1 + standard_die_probability 3 + standard_die_probability 5) - (standard_die_probability 2 + standard_die_probability 4 + standard_die_probability 6)) / 6 = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A standard six-sided die has equal probability of landing on each of its faces. What is the difference between the sum of probabilities of the odd-numbered faces (1, 3, and 5) and the sum of probabilities of the even-numbered faces (2, 4, and 6) divided by 6? The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. probability x = x / 21"
and h1 : "probability 1 + probability 3 + probability 5 = (11 / 21)"
shows  "probability 1 + probability 3 + probability 5 = 11 / 21"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. probability x = x / 21"
and h1 : "probability 1 + probability 3 + probability 5 = (11 / 21)"
shows  "probability 1 + probability 3 + probability 5 = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Three events have probabilities given by the function $P(x) = \frac{x}{21}$. If $P(1) + P(3) + P(5) = \frac{11}{21}$, confirm that the sum of the probabilities of these three events is indeed equal to $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_odd = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1,3,5}. (1/6) * (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (if j = i then 0 else (1/5))))"
shows  "prob_odd = 11 / 21"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_odd = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1,3,5}. (1/6) * (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (if j = i then 0 else (1/5))))"
shows  "prob_odd = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a two-step experiment where, in the first step, a fair 6-sided die is rolled, and in the second step, another fair 6-sided die is rolled only if the result of the first step is not 1, 3, or 5. Calculate the probability that the first step results in an odd number. The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "P_odd = (\<Sum>k \<in> {1, 3, 5}. (1 / 21) * (6 - k))"
shows  "P_odd = 11 / 21"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "P_odd = (\<Sum>k \<in> {1, 3, 5}. (1 / 21) * (6 - k))"
shows  "P_odd = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the sum of the odd integers from 1 to 5, multiplied by $\frac{1}{21}$ and subtracted from 6. The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. probability n = 1 / 21"
and h1 : "probability 1 + probability 3 + probability 5 = p"
shows  "p = 11 / 21"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 On a standard die one of the dots is removed at random with each dot equally likely to be chosen. The die is then rolled. What is the probability that the top face has an odd number of dots? The final Answer is \frac{11}{21}
 ### Proof
 The dot is chosen from the face with $n$ dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$.
 Thus the face that originally has $n$ dots is left with an odd number of dots with probability $\frac{n}{21}$ if $n$ is even and $1 - n/21$ if $n$ is odd. Each face is the top face with probability $\frac{1}{6}$.
 Therefore the top face has an odd number of dots with probability \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6}\displaystyle\left(\displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{1}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{2}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)
 + \frac{4}{21} + \displaystyle\left(1 - \frac{5}{21}\displaystyle\right) + \frac{6}{21}\displaystyle\right) \\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6} \displaystyle\left(3 + \frac{3}{21}\displaystyle\right)\\ & \qquad = \frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{66}{21} \\
 & \qquad = \boxed{\frac{11}{21}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. probability n = 1 / 21"
and h1 : "probability 1 + probability 3 + probability 5 = p"
shows  "p = 11 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A probability function assigns a probability of $\frac{1}{21}$ to each integer $n$. What is the probability $p$ that $n$ is an odd integer among $1$, $3$, and $5$? The final answer is $\frac{11}{21}$.
